request_pathways.name: HCA Authorization for Release of PHI
Fax submission to HCA processing center
Mail to HCA PO Box 290789, Nashville, TN 37229-0789

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient uses a generic HCA Healthcare system-wide HIPAA authorization form that serves both patient self-access and third-party release, with a radio-button option to indicate 'At the request of the individual.'

red_flags: Requests last 4 digits of SSN (marked optional but unnecessary for records authorization)
No distinction between Right of Access fee limits/timelines and general third-party authorization practices
Fax delivery restricted to physician offices/medical facilities only
bright_spots: USCDI (United States Core Data for Interoperability) release option — rare and forward-looking
Four electronic delivery format options (paper, electronic media, encrypted email, unencrypted email) with risk disclosures
Full Spanish-language translation available alongside English version
52 fillable fields enabling fully digital form completion
Alternative digital pathways available (Swellbox portal, MyHealthONE patient portal)

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation — form is directly linked from the 'For Patients → Medical Records' page on the Sunrise Health website, though the hospital domain redirects to the system site.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 4: Mostly digital workflow — the form is fully fillable with 52 interactive fields (digital completion without printing), but submission requires fax, mail, or using a separate portal rather than integrated digital submission from the PDF itself.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with minor clarity issues — three clear sections with logical flow and 16 granular record-type checkboxes, but the single-page density is high and terms like USCDI/NPI are unexplained jargon.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the generic authorization form accommodates patient self-access via a radio button but is framed around third-party release, with no Right of Access distinction, recipient-focused fields, and fee language that doesn't acknowledge HIPAA access fee limits.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Some requirements beyond what the law requires — SSN collection (even optional) is unnecessary, 'reasonable copy fee' language may mislead patients about Right of Access fee limits, and no response time commitment is stated despite HIPAA's 30-day requirement.

overall.summary: MountainView Hospital offers a technically well-built, fillable authorization form with multilingual support and modern features like USCDI, but its generic third-party release framing and lack of a dedicated patient access pathway limit patient-centeredness.
